description: From Middle English amblen, from Old French ambler (“walk as a horse does”), from Old Occitan amblar, from Latin ambulō (“I walk”). Doublet of ambulate.

entries.meaning: An unhurried leisurely walk or stroll.
An easy gait, especially that of a horse.

verbs.description: amble (third-person singular simple present ambles, present participle ambling, simple past and past participle ambled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To stroll or walk slowly and leisurely.
(intransitive) Of a quadruped: to move along by using both legs on one side, and then the other.
